Security Report

November 1 2025, 00:20:53 am (UTC+0000)

C 173 H 371 M 47 L 2 W 0

Usage of unsafe Pickle libraries critical

Rule ID: python_lang_avoid_pickle  CWE: CWE 502  Fingerprint: 5a7fcc7c8ff723f8a921bfa9a4a7a545_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/anyio/to_interpreter.py:114

114 item = pickle.dumps((func, args), pickle.HIGHEST_PROTOCOL)

Description

Using pickle, _pickle and cPickle can make your application vulnerable to unsafe code execution. This is because the deserialization logic of these libraries allows for arbitrary code execution. It is best practices to avoid these libraries and to use a safer serialization formats like JSON.

Remediations

  • Do not use pickle or its derivatives for deserialization wherever possible. These libraries are open to security vulnerabilities.

  • Do use recommended safer formats like JSON, Protocol Buffers (protobuf) and MessagePack.

    import msgpack #MessagePack

data = {'key': 'value'}
packed_data = msgpack.packb(data)

References

  • OWASP Deserialization cheat sheet

Usage of unsafe Pickle libraries critical

Rule ID: python_lang_avoid_pickle  CWE: CWE 502  Fingerprint: 5a7fcc7c8ff723f8a921bfa9a4a7a545_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/anyio/to_interpreter.py:123

123 res = pickle.loads(res)

Description

Remediations

  • Do use recommended safer formats like JSON, Protocol Buffers (protobuf) and MessagePack.

packed_data = msgpack.packb(data)

Unsanitized external input in code generation critical

Rule ID: python_lang_code_injection  CWE: CWE 94  Fingerprint: 5913e4290e3a5ab3cbee1df3ec69a376_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cffi/api.py:849

849 setattr(FFILibrary, name, property( 850 lambda self: read_variable(BType, name), 851 lambda self, value: write_variable(BType, name, value)))

Description

Allowing external input (dynamic or user-controlled) to directly influence code generation or scripting functions without proper sanitization can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This occurs when an attacker is able to insert malicious code into your application, which is then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or data access.

Remediations

  • Do not pass unsanitized external input to functions or methods that dynamically execute code.
  • Do always validate or sanitize input to ensure it does not contain harmful code before using it in such contexts.

References

  • OWASP Code injection

Unsanitized external input in code generation critical

Rule ID: python_lang_code_injection  CWE: CWE 94  Fingerprint: 5913e4290e3a5ab3cbee1df3ec69a376_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cffi/api.py:921

921 setattr(self, name, value)

Description

Allowing external input (dynamic or user-controlled) to directly influence code generation or scripting functions without proper sanitization can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This occurs when an attacker is able to insert malicious code into your application, which is then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or data access.

Remediations

  • Do not pass unsanitized external input to functions or methods that dynamically execute code.
  • Do always validate or sanitize input to ensure it does not contain harmful code before using it in such contexts.

References

  • OWASP Code injection

Unsanitized external input in code generation critical

Rule ID: python_lang_code_injection  CWE: CWE 94  Fingerprint: 7485781ac18492b3e21b1b74f993ddc3_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cffi/backend_ctypes.py:812

812 setattr(self._blob, fname, BField._to_ctypes(value))

Description

Allowing external input (dynamic or user-controlled) to directly influence code generation or scripting functions without proper sanitization can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This occurs when an attacker is able to insert malicious code into your application, which is then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or data access.

Remediations

  • Do not pass unsanitized external input to functions or methods that dynamically execute code.
  • Do always validate or sanitize input to ensure it does not contain harmful code before using it in such contexts.

References

  • OWASP Code injection

831 setattr(self._blob, fname, value)

45 mod = __import__(mod, None, None, [cls])

Description

Allowing external input (dynamic or user-controlled) to directly influence code generation or scripting functions without proper sanitization can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This occurs when an attacker is able to insert malicious code into your application, which is then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or data access.

Remediations

  • Do not pass unsanitized external input to functions or methods that dynamically execute code.
  • Do always validate or sanitize input to ensure it does not contain harmful code before using it in such contexts.

References

  • OWASP Code injection

Unsanitized external input in code generation critical

Rule ID: python_lang_code_injection  CWE: CWE 94  Fingerprint: 62f5ca048c8f1967dccaaceabf672cd6_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/dialects/__init__.py:48

48 module = __import__("sqlalchemy.dialects.%s" % (dialect,)).dialects

Description

Allowing external input (dynamic or user-controlled) to directly influence code generation or scripting functions without proper sanitization can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This occurs when an attacker is able to insert malicious code into your application, which is then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or data access.

Remediations

  • Do not pass unsanitized external input to functions or methods that dynamically execute code.
  • Do always validate or sanitize input to ensure it does not contain harmful code before using it in such contexts.

References

  • OWASP Code injection

766 setattr(obj, sub_aliased_insp.class_.__name__, ent)

Description

Allowing external input (dynamic or user-controlled) to directly influence code generation or scripting functions without proper sanitization can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This occurs when an attacker is able to insert malicious code into your application, which is then executed, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or data access.

Remediations

  • Do not pass unsanitized external input to functions or methods that dynamically execute code.
  • Do always validate or sanitize input to ensure it does not contain harmful code before using it in such contexts.

References

  • OWASP Code injection

Unsanitized external input in code generation critical

Rule ID: python_lang_code_injection  CWE: CWE 94  Fingerprint: 2a6a284caffcf6c6fe441470457ec8f2_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/orm/util.py:795

795 setattr(self, key, attr)

Description

Unsanitized external input in code generation critical

Unsanitized user input in 'eval' type function critical

Rule ID: python_lang_eval_using_user_input  CWE: CWE 95  Fingerprint: 2dfad70b574dc122c00296ffc3944469_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/passlib/crypto/digest.py:1000

1000 eval(code, gdict, ldict)

Description

Executing code with ‘eval’ or similar functions using unsanitized user input is risky and can lead to code injection vulnerabilities. This happens when external input is used directly in functions that execute code, allowing attackers to run malicious code within your application.

Remediations

  • Do not use eval or similar code execution functions with unsanitized user input. This can create a significant security risk by allowing code injection.
  • Do not use ast.literal_eval() with unsanitized user input. While literal_eval is often considered to be less risky than eval because it evaluates strings as Python data structures only (integers, strings, dictionaries,etc), an attacker could exploit this function with deeply nested structures that could cause excessive memory allocation or stack consumption.

  • Do use dynamic hardcoded values instead of direct user input to mitigate the risk of code injection. This approach allows for controlled execution of code without exposing your application to injected malicious code. For example, use a dictionary to store functions, and call these based on user input.

    def total_with_vat(a, b):
total = a + b
return total + total * 0.15

def total_without_vat(a, b):
return a + b

get_total = {
"incl_vat": total_with_vat,
"excl_vat": total_without_vat
}

if form.cleaned_data["include_vat"]:
total_func = get_total["incl_vat"]
total = total_func(a, b)

# ...

References

  • OWASP Code injection explained

Unsanitized user input in OS command critical

Rule ID: python_lang_os_command_injection  CWE: CWE 78  Fingerprint: 2308904fca281230b7de9a64034587d6_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/dotenv/cli.py:213

213 p = Popen(command, universal_newlines=True, bufsize=0, shell=False, env=cmd_env)

Description

Directly incorporating external or user-defined input into an OS command exposes the system to possible command injection attacks. This vulnerability allows attackers to execute unauthorized commands on the operating system, potentially leading to a compromise of system integrity.

Remediations

  • Do not use OS commands that include dynamic input directly. Instead, explore safer alternatives such as libraries or built-in functions that achieve the same goal without executing system commands.
  • Do use hardcoded values for any input that is incorporated into OS commands. This approach minimizes the risk by ensuring only predefined inputs are used, thus preventing attackers from injecting malicious commands. Use safe lists or dictionaries if you need to be dynamic.

References

  • OWASP command injection explained

Unsanitized user input in OS command critical

Rule ID: python_lang_os_command_injection  CWE: CWE 78  Fingerprint: c2bd508398be69d94cab9b87b1fc9e28_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/commands/configuration.py:247

247 subprocess.check_call(f'{editor} "{fname}"', shell=True)

Description

Directly incorporating external or user-defined input into an OS command exposes the system to possible command injection attacks. This vulnerability allows attackers to execute unauthorized commands on the operating system, potentially leading to a compromise of system integrity.

Remediations

  • Do not use OS commands that include dynamic input directly. Instead, explore safer alternatives such as libraries or built-in functions that achieve the same goal without executing system commands.
  • Do use hardcoded values for any input that is incorporated into OS commands. This approach minimizes the risk by ensuring only predefined inputs are used, thus preventing attackers from injecting malicious commands. Use safe lists or dictionaries if you need to be dynamic.

References

  • OWASP command injection explained

Unsanitized external input in SQL query critical

Rule ID: python_lang_sql_injection  CWE: CWE 89  Fingerprint: 49ed16d5711e52c66d5834718031cd9f_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py:705

705 c.execute(self.init_command)

Description

Using unsanitized data, such as user input or request data, or externally influenced data passed to a function, in SQL query exposes your application to SQL injection attacks. This vulnerability arises when externally controlled data is directly included in SQL statements without proper sanitation, allowing attackers to manipulate queries and access or modify data.

Remediations

  • Do not include raw external input in SQL queries. This practice can lead to SQL injection vulnerabilities.

    sorting_order = request.GET["untrusted"]
query = f"SELECT id, name FROM products ORDER BY name LIMIT 20 {sorting_order};"; # unsafe

  • Do validate all external input to ensure it meets the expected format before including it in SQL queries.

    sorting_order = "DESC" if request.GET["sortingOrder"] == "DESC" else "ASC"

  • Do use parameters for database queries to separate SQL logic from external input, significantly reducing the risk of SQL injection.

    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM products WHERE id LIKE ?", [f"%{product_id}%"])

  • Do escape all external input using appropriate database-specific escaping functions before including it in SQL queries.

    from mysql.connector.conversion import MySQLConverter

converter = MySQLConverter(connection)
ok = converter.escape(request.GET["value"])

References

  • OWASP SQL injection explained
  • OWASP SQL injection prevention cheat sheet

Unsanitized external input in SQL query critical

Rule ID: python_lang_sql_injection  CWE: CWE 89  Fingerprint: 3885a17dfde91ad4b9be164285c8372e_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/connectors/asyncio.py:362

362 cursor.execute(operation, parameters)

Description

Using unsanitized data, such as user input or request data, or externally influenced data passed to a function, in SQL query exposes your application to SQL injection attacks. This vulnerability arises when externally controlled data is directly included in SQL statements without proper sanitation, allowing attackers to manipulate queries and access or modify data.

Remediations

  • Do not include raw external input in SQL queries. This practice can lead to SQL injection vulnerabilities.

  • Do validate all external input to ensure it meets the expected format before including it in SQL queries.

  • Do use parameters for database queries to separate SQL logic from external input, significantly reducing the risk of SQL injection.

    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM products WHERE id LIKE ?", [f"%{product_id}%"])

  • Do escape all external input using appropriate database-specific escaping functions before including it in SQL queries.

    from mysql.connector.conversion import MySQLConverter

converter = MySQLConverter(connection)
ok = converter.escape(request.GET["value"])

  • OWASP SQL injection explained
  • OWASP SQL injection prevention cheat sheet

Unsanitized external input in SQL query critical

Rule ID: python_lang_sql_injection  CWE: CWE 89  Fingerprint: b4744661081d9f2c24fadaffe55ca368_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/dialects/postgresql/_psycopg_common.py:183

183 cursor.execute(self._dialect_specific_select_one)

Description

Using unsanitized data, such as user input or request data, or externally influenced data passed to a function, in SQL query exposes your application to SQL injection attacks. This vulnerability arises when externally controlled data is directly included in SQL statements without proper sanitation, allowing attackers to manipulate queries and access or modify data.

Remediations

  • Do not include raw external input in SQL queries. This practice can lead to SQL injection vulnerabilities.

    sorting_order = request.GET["untrusted"]

  • Do validate all external input to ensure it meets the expected format before including it in SQL queries.

    sorting_order = "DESC" if request.GET["sortingOrder"] == "DESC" else "ASC"

  • Do use parameters for database queries to separate SQL logic from external input, significantly reducing the risk of SQL injection.

    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM products WHERE id LIKE ?", [f"%{product_id}%"])

  • Do escape all external input using appropriate database-specific escaping functions before including it in SQL queries.

    from mysql.connector.conversion import MySQLConverter

converter = MySQLConverter(connection)
ok = converter.escape(request.GET["value"])

References

  • OWASP SQL injection explained
  • OWASP SQL injection prevention cheat sheet

Unsanitized external input in SQL query critical

Rule ID: python_lang_sql_injection  CWE: CWE 89  Fingerprint: b9ad869c498e5e119582e2ac92dc4a66_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/dialects/postgresql/pg8000.py:536

536 cursor.execute( 537 "SET SESSION CHARACTERISTICS AS TRANSACTION " 538 f"ISOLATION LEVEL {level}" 539 )

Description

Using unsanitized data, such as user input or request data, or externally influenced data passed to a function, in SQL query exposes your application to SQL injection attacks. This vulnerability arises when externally controlled data is directly included in SQL statements without proper sanitation, allowing attackers to manipulate queries and access or modify data.

Remediations

  • Do not include raw external input in SQL queries. This practice can lead to SQL injection vulnerabilities.

    sorting_order = request.GET["untrusted"]
query = f"SELECT id, name FROM products ORDER BY name LIMIT 20 {sorting_order};"; # unsafe

  • Do validate all external input to ensure it meets the expected format before including it in SQL queries.

    sorting_order = "DESC" if request.GET["sortingOrder"] == "DESC" else "ASC"

  • Do use parameters for database queries to separate SQL logic from external input, significantly reducing the risk of SQL injection.

    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM products WHERE id LIKE ?", [f"%{product_id}%"])

  • Do escape all external input using appropriate database-specific escaping functions before including it in SQL queries.

    from mysql.connector.conversion import MySQLConverter

converter = MySQLConverter(connection)
ok = converter.escape(request.GET["value"])

  • OWASP SQL injection explained
  • OWASP SQL injection prevention cheat sheet

Permissive file assignment high

Rule ID: python_lang_file_permissions  CWE: CWE 732  Fingerprint: a0e0338520ecde43c9053c80b24564d3_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/utils/unpacking.py:47

47 mask = os.umask(0)

Description

Permissive file assignment exposes sensitive information by granting unnecessary read, write, or execute permissions to users without ownership privileges.

Remediations

  • Do keep file permissions as restrictive as possible to minimize the risk of unauthorized access. Use the principle of least privilege to only grant permissions that are absolutely necessary for the operation of the application.

    os.chmod("my_private_file.txt", 0o600) # only you have full read and write access

  • Do prefer assigning file permissions to ‘groups’ rather than ‘other’ when you need to extend privileges to users who are not the owners. This approach helps in limiting access to a more controlled set of users.

  • Do not set a permissive umask value, as this can lead to overly permissive default permissions for new files and directories

    os.umask(0) # unsafe

Permissive file assignment high

Rule ID: python_lang_file_permissions  CWE: CWE 732  Fingerprint: 870e57884c4e9047147d05a914691b13_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pyfakefs/fake_os.py:216

216 mask = os.umask(0)

Description

Permissive file assignment exposes sensitive information by granting unnecessary read, write, or execute permissions to users without ownership privileges.

Remediations

  • Do keep file permissions as restrictive as possible to minimize the risk of unauthorized access. Use the principle of least privilege to only grant permissions that are absolutely necessary for the operation of the application.

    os.chmod("my_private_file.txt", 0o600) # only you have full read and write access

  • Do prefer assigning file permissions to ‘groups’ rather than ‘other’ when you need to extend privileges to users who are not the owners. This approach helps in limiting access to a more controlled set of users.

  • Do not set a permissive umask value, as this can lead to overly permissive default permissions for new files and directories

    os.umask(0) # unsafe

Usage of manual HTML sanitization (XSS) high

Rule ID: python_lang_manual_html_sanitization  CWE: CWE 79  Fingerprint: bf6766abb1ec5020869ea4e8fe2325d1_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/rich/jupyter.py:62

62 return text.replace("&", "&amp;").replace("<", "&lt;").replace(">", "&gt;")

Description

Manually sanitizing HTML is prone to mistakes and can lead to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities. This occurs when user input is not properly sanitized, allowing attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users.

Remediations

  • Do not manually escape HTML to sanitize user input. This method is unreliable and can easily miss certain exploits.

    sanitized_value = user_input.replace('<', '&lt;').replace('>', '&gt;'); # unsafe
html = f"<strong>{sanitized_value}</strong>"

  • Do use a trusted HTML sanitization library to handle user input safely. Libraries designed for sanitization are more reliable as they cover a wide range of XSS attack vectors.

    from html_sanitizer import Sanitizer

sanitizer = Sanitizer()
sanitized_value = sanitizer.sanitize(user_input)

html = f"<strong>{sanitized_value}</strong>"

References

  • OWASP XSS explained

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 8d4bd63fa9be10f47cf08cf739612471_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cffi/_imp_emulation.py:56

56 package_directory = os.path.join(entry, name)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

59 file_path = os.path.join(package_directory, package_file_name)

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

  open(my_path)

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 8d4bd63fa9be10f47cf08cf739612471_6

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cffi/_imp_emulation.py:77

77 file = open(file_path, mode, encoding=encoding)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 2a354649f2888026d7f64bd8588e6e92_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cffi/setuptools_ext.py:22

22 with open(filename) as f:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 6d6d20e07a9ac62ab0c81be6c0683f98_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/build_env.py:273

273 os.mkdir(self._site_dir)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: c4ecadc67b4646f8176eb3b0bf10604b_10

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/commands/install.py:577

577 os.remove(target_item_dir)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: c4ecadc67b4646f8176eb3b0bf10604b_11

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/commands/install.py:579

579 shutil.move(os.path.join(lib_dir, item), target_item_dir)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: b9731566e6b9b48bcaa5ec6e8513c7fd_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/operations/freeze.py:62

62 with open(req_file_path) as req_file:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 3fd363f280687444be19b6b808827f3f_9

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_install.py:705

705 if os.path.exists(archive_path):

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: aad01822645a3186999fa2eea48f3c9b_16

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_uninstall.py:516

516 easy_install_pth = os.path.join( 517 os.path.dirname(normalized_dist_location), 518 "easy-install.pth", 519 )

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_uninstall.py:520

520 paths_to_remove.add_pth(easy_install_pth, "./" + easy_install_egg)

Remediations

  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: c0741e824d02a42a1134bfe9fa05d7e4_3

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/utils/unpacking.py:130

130 if not is_within_directory(location, fn):

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/utils/unpacking.py:135

  open(my_path)

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/vcs/subversion.py:136

136 if os.path.exists(entries_path):

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: d1c1d4bec58aa898a1c8bc99dfad5da8_3

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/distlib/scripts.py:344

344 script = os.path.join(self.source_dir, convert_path(script))

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 35a7429a7379d871a89371cffe331c1d_14

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/distro/distro.py:1292

1292 filepath = os.path.join(self.etc_dir, basename)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 94664aa01b3a6e1ff6307409b1e45964_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pyproject_hooks/_in_process/_in_process.py:37

37 with open(path, encoding="utf-8") as f:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 94664aa01b3a6e1ff6307409b1e45964_2

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pyproject_hooks/_in_process/_in_process.py:235

235 with open(os.path.join(metadata_directory, WHEEL_BUILT_MARKER), "wb"):

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 2716281f68dddda687780d8033f4b640_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pydantic/v1/mypy.py:948

948 with open(config_file, read_mode) as rf:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 28f0218a39763abea1953144ee71d846_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pydantic/v1/parse.py:57

57 b = path.read_bytes()

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 13ee1b277ab388ec7b1f387b6aab4442_2

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/util/tool_support.py:145

145 with open(tempfile) as tf:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

References

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: 13ee1b277ab388ec7b1f387b6aab4442_3

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/util/tool_support.py:147

147 os.unlink(tempfile)

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

  • OWASP Path Traversal

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/sqlalchemy/util/tool_support.py:161

161 with open(source_file, encoding="utf-8") as tf:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

168 with open(destination_path, encoding="utf-8") as dp:

Remediations

  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/starlette/config.py:113

113 with open(file_name, encoding=encoding) as input_file:

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

  open(my_path)

Unsanitized dynamic input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_traversal  CWE: CWE 22  Fingerprint: e9b6e5744023423a9dfe5afd1d1cc2cb_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/uvicorn/main.py:598

598 os.remove(config.uds) # pragma: py-win32

Description

Using unsanitized dynamic input to determine file paths can allow attackers to gain access to files and folders outside of the intended scope. This vulnerability occurs when input provided by users is directly used to access the filesystem without proper validation or sanitization.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use external input to construct file paths. This can lead to unauthorized file access.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do use absolute path checks to confirm that the constructed path is within the expected directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, dynamic_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Unsanitized user input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_using_user_input  CWE: CWE 73  Fingerprint: e40dbc22e6846e7afa2b10b5be11616e_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/jproperties.py:1004

1004 f = open(sys.argv[1], "rb")

Description

Unsanitized user input in file path resolution can lead to security vulnerabilities. This issue arises when an application directly uses input from the user to determine file paths or names without proper validation or sanitization. Attackers can exploit this to access unauthorized files or directories, leading to data breaches or other security compromises.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use user input in file paths without sanitization. This prevents attackers from manipulating file paths to access or manipulate unauthorized files.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do sanitize user input used in file path resolution. For example, use absolute paths and check against the expected base directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, user_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Unsanitized user input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_using_user_input  CWE: CWE 73  Fingerprint: abba88f9765ea897dbf4f3f0a6dedd19_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/dependency_groups/_lint_dependency_groups.py:32

32 with open(args.pyproject_file, "rb") as fp:

Description

Unsanitized user input in file path resolution can lead to security vulnerabilities. This issue arises when an application directly uses input from the user to determine file paths or names without proper validation or sanitization. Attackers can exploit this to access unauthorized files or directories, leading to data breaches or other security compromises.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use user input in file paths without sanitization. This prevents attackers from manipulating file paths to access or manipulate unauthorized files.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do sanitize user input used in file path resolution. For example, use absolute paths and check against the expected base directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, user_input))

if my_path.startswith(BASE_DIRECTORY):
  open(my_path)

Unsanitized user input in file path high

Rule ID: python_lang_path_using_user_input  CWE: CWE 73  Fingerprint: f80a0ff5697590ada54b1888f703fee2_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/dependency_groups/_pip_wrapper.py:35

35 with open(args.pyproject_file, "rb") as fp:

Description

Unsanitized user input in file path resolution can lead to security vulnerabilities. This issue arises when an application directly uses input from the user to determine file paths or names without proper validation or sanitization. Attackers can exploit this to access unauthorized files or directories, leading to data breaches or other security compromises.

Remediations

  • Do not directly use user input in file paths without sanitization. This prevents attackers from manipulating file paths to access or manipulate unauthorized files.
  • Do use a safelist to define accessible paths or directories. Only allow user input to influence file paths within these predefined, safe boundaries.

  • Do sanitize user input used in file path resolution. For example, use absolute paths and check against the expected base directory

    BASE_DIRECTORY = '/path/to/safe/directory'
my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(BASE_DIRECTORY, user_input))

  open(my_path)

Usage of external input in code reflection high

Rule ID: python_lang_reflection_using_user_input  CWE: CWE 470  Fingerprint: 80d56c78092534537a4c6835f8a4dec1_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/pyproject_hooks/_in_process/_in_process.py:367

367 hook = globals()[hook_name]

Description

Using external input for dynamic class loading or code execution through reflection poses a significant security risk. This practice can be exploited by attackers to load harmful classes or execute malicious methods, potentially resulting in remote code execution and other severe security threats.

Remediations

  • Do not - wherever possible - use external input with code reflection. Avoiding this practice altogether significantly lowers the risk of executing unauthorized or malicious code.
  • Do limit the allowed class names and method names to a predefined safelist. This approach restricts the scope of classes and methods that can be dynamically accessed, reducing the risk of unauthorized actions.
  • Do sanitize external input by removing special and unexpected characters that could facilitate code injection attacks. Characters such as single or double quotation marks and backslashes are particularly risky and should be filtered out.

Usage of weak hashing library on a password (SHA-1) high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_password_encryption_sha1  CWE: CWE 326  Fingerprint: 6e32dbd4f11bc878a2915913d1658c90_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/requests/auth.py:205

205 cnonce = hashlib.sha1(s).hexdigest()[:16]

Description

Using a weak hashing library like SHA-1 for passwords increases the risk of data breaches. SHA-1 is vulnerable to collision attacks, where two different inputs can produce the same hash value, compromising data integrity and security.

Remediations

  • Do not use SHA-1 for hashing passwords. This algorithm is no longer considered secure and can make your system vulnerable to attacks.

    hashlib.sha1(user.password).digest() #unsafe

  • Do use stronger hashing algorithms such as SHA-256 to enhance the security of stored passwords.

    hashlib.sha256(user.password).digest()

Usage of weak hashing library on a password (SHA-1) high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_password_encryption_sha1  CWE: CWE 326  Fingerprint: 4dda87035fcf25cbfdb794076ad371ba_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/requests/auth.py:205

205 cnonce = hashlib.sha1(s).hexdigest()[:16]

Description

Using a weak hashing library like SHA-1 for passwords increases the risk of data breaches. SHA-1 is vulnerable to collision attacks, where two different inputs can produce the same hash value, compromising data integrity and security.

Remediations

  • Do not use SHA-1 for hashing passwords. This algorithm is no longer considered secure and can make your system vulnerable to attacks.

    hashlib.sha1(user.password).digest() #unsafe

  • Do use stronger hashing algorithms such as SHA-256 to enhance the security of stored passwords.

    hashlib.sha256(user.password).digest()

Usage of weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_random  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: b5a9f634562a1fde20f4f153a3090a5c_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/click/_compat.py:429

429 f".__atomic-write{random.randrange(1 << 32):08x}",

Description

The random module in Python generates pseudorandom numbers that are not secure for cryptographic purposes. These numbers can be predicted if the seed is known, posing a risk to the security of applications that use them for generating secrets, tokens, or other security-sensitive elements.

Remediations

  • Do use secrets instead of random for generating random numbers in contexts where security is crucial. This ensures the randomness is cryptographically secure and unpredictable.
  • Do not use random for generating random numbers in cryptographic applications, including but not limited to key generation, authentication tokens, or security challenges.
  • Do not initialize random with predictable seeds, such as timestamps or other easily guessable values, if it is required to use random.

References

  • secrets module documentation

Usage of weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_random  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: f37e0fbf74f51282a42d6dbe9ff2643f_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/asymmetric/rsa.py:265

265 a = random.randint(2, n - 1)

  • Do not use random for generating random numbers in cryptographic applications, including but not limited to key generation, authentication tokens, or security challenges.
  • Do not initialize random with predictable seeds, such as timestamps or other easily guessable values, if it is required to use random.

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_tls_version  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: 2d1d3ead849a8874874c71f8b38d86cf_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/urllib3/contrib/pyopenssl.py:99

99 ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1: OpenSSL.SSL.TLSv1_METHOD,

Description

TLS (Transport Layer Security) versions 1.0 and 1.1 have known vulnerabilities and using them introduces security risks to your application. These outdated TLS versions can lead to the interception and compromise of sensitive data during transmission.

Remediations

  • Do enforce the use of TLS 1.3 when configuring SSL. TLS 1.3 offers significant security improvements, helping to protect data from known vulnerabilities present in older versions.

    context = ssl.create_default_context(ssl.Purpose.CLIENT_AUTH)
context.minimum_version = ssl.TLSVersion.TLSv1_3

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

  • Do not configure your server to accept TLS versions 1.0 or 1.1. Removing these options from your TLS configuration is crucial to prevent downgrade attacks.

References

  • IETF’s Deprecation of TLS 1.0 and 1.1
  • OWASP TLS Cheat Sheet
  • Python ssl module documentation

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_tls_version  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: 2d1d3ead849a8874874c71f8b38d86cf_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/urllib3/contrib/pyopenssl.py:103

103 _openssl_versions[ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv3] = OpenSSL.SSL.SSLv3_METHOD

Description

TLS (Transport Layer Security) versions 1.0 and 1.1 have known vulnerabilities and using them introduces security risks to your application. These outdated TLS versions can lead to the interception and compromise of sensitive data during transmission.

Remediations

  • Do enforce the use of TLS 1.3 when configuring SSL. TLS 1.3 offers significant security improvements, helping to protect data from known vulnerabilities present in older versions.

    context = ssl.create_default_context(ssl.Purpose.CLIENT_AUTH)
context.minimum_version = ssl.TLSVersion.TLSv1_3

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

  • Do not configure your server to accept TLS versions 1.0 or 1.1. Removing these options from your TLS configuration is crucial to prevent downgrade attacks.

References

  • IETF’s Deprecation of TLS 1.0 and 1.1
  • OWASP TLS Cheat Sheet
  • Python ssl module documentation

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_tls_version  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: 2d1d3ead849a8874874c71f8b38d86cf_2

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_tls_version  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: d8940df048e3a5c064915a301399e30c_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/urllib3/contrib/securetransport.py:172

172 _protocol_to_min_max[ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1] = (

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

  • Python ssl module documentation

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_tls_version  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: d8940df048e3a5c064915a301399e30c_2

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_vendor/urllib3/contrib/securetransport.py:177

177 _protocol_to_min_max[ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_1] = (

Description

TLS (Transport Layer Security) versions 1.0 and 1.1 have known vulnerabilities and using them introduces security risks to your application. These outdated TLS versions can lead to the interception and compromise of sensitive data during transmission.

Remediations

  • Do enforce the use of TLS 1.3 when configuring SSL. TLS 1.3 offers significant security improvements, helping to protect data from known vulnerabilities present in older versions.

    context = ssl.create_default_context(ssl.Purpose.CLIENT_AUTH)
context.minimum_version = ssl.TLSVersion.TLSv1_3

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

  • Do not configure your server to accept TLS versions 1.0 or 1.1. Removing these options from your TLS configuration is crucial to prevent downgrade attacks.

References

  • IETF’s Deprecation of TLS 1.0 and 1.1
  • OWASP TLS Cheat Sheet
  • Python ssl module documentation

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_tls_version  CWE: CWE 327  Fingerprint: 5a1f3601c8a82496c0224802e7c718b3_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/urllib3/contrib/pyopenssl.py:73

73 ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1: OpenSSL.SSL.TLSv1_METHOD,

Description

TLS (Transport Layer Security) versions 1.0 and 1.1 have known vulnerabilities and using them introduces security risks to your application. These outdated TLS versions can lead to the interception and compromise of sensitive data during transmission.

Remediations

  • Do enforce the use of TLS 1.3 when configuring SSL. TLS 1.3 offers significant security improvements, helping to protect data from known vulnerabilities present in older versions.

    context = ssl.create_default_context(ssl.Purpose.CLIENT_AUTH)
context.minimum_version = ssl.TLSVersion.TLSv1_3

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

  • Do not configure your server to accept TLS versions 1.0 or 1.1. Removing these options from your TLS configuration is crucial to prevent downgrade attacks.

References

  • IETF’s Deprecation of TLS 1.0 and 1.1
  • OWASP TLS Cheat Sheet
  • Python ssl module documentation

Usage of deprecated TLS version high

Remediations

  • Do enforce the use of TLS 1.3 when configuring SSL. TLS 1.3 offers significant security improvements, helping to protect data from known vulnerabilities present in older versions.

    context = ssl.create_default_context(ssl.Purpose.CLIENT_AUTH)

  • Do utilize configurations that support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) with TLS 1.3. PFS enhances security by ensuring that past communications remain secure even if future session keys are compromised.

  • Do not configure your server to accept TLS versions 1.0 or 1.1. Removing these options from your TLS configuration is crucial to prevent downgrade attacks.

Leakage of information in logger message low

Rule ID: javascript_lang_logger_leak  CWE: CWE 532  Fingerprint: cba913cf4b28331aab3dc34c3d5333fd_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/urllib3/contrib/emscripten/emscripten_fetch_worker.js:40

40 console.log("Request exception:", error);

Description

Information leakage through logger messages can compromise sensitive data. This vulnerability arises when dynamic data or variables, which may contain sensitive information, are included in log messages.

Remediations

  • Do not include sensitive data directly in logger messages. This can lead to the exposure of such data in log files, which might be accessible to unauthorized individuals.

    logger.info(`Results: ${data}`) // unsafe

  • Do use logging levels appropriately to control the verbosity of log output and minimize the risk of leaking sensitive information in production environments.

Leakage of information in logger message low

Rule ID: javascript_lang_logger_leak  CWE: CWE 532  Fingerprint: cba913cf4b28331aab3dc34c3d5333fd_1

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/urllib3/contrib/emscripten/emscripten_fetch_worker.js:100

100 console.log("Request exception:", error);

Description

Information leakage through logger messages can compromise sensitive data. This vulnerability arises when dynamic data or variables, which may contain sensitive information, are included in log messages.

Remediations

  • Do not include sensitive data directly in logger messages. This can lead to the exposure of such data in log files, which might be accessible to unauthorized individuals.

    logger.info(`Results: ${data}`) // unsafe

  • Do use logging levels appropriately to control the verbosity of log output and minimize the risk of leaking sensitive information in production environments.

Leakage of sensitive data in exception message medium

Rule ID: python_lang_exception  CWE: CWE 210  Fingerprint: dea7dc342dda957f784f54e533528860_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/fastapi/encoders.py:341

341 raise ValueError(errors) from e

Description

Leakage of sensitive data in exception messages can lead to data breaches. This vulnerability occurs when sensitive information is included in exceptions, making it accessible to unauthorized users.

Remediations

  • Do not include sensitive data in exception messages. This can inadvertently expose private information.

    raise Exception(f"User '{user.email}' is unauthorized") # unsafe

  • Do use non-sensitive, unique identifiers in exception messages to avoid revealing personal information.

    raise Exception(f"User '{user.uuid}' is unauthorized") # unsafe

Leakage of sensitive data in exception message medium

Rule ID: python_lang_exception  CWE: CWE 210  Fingerprint: 1395ba2bec17cccf766aa2294b7d0bea_0

Leakage of sensitive information in logger message medium

Rule ID: python_lang_logger  CWE: CWE 532  Fingerprint: 30d8561076cd79f50d3ef68861121017_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/pip/_internal/resolution/resolvelib/reporter.py:50

50 logger.info("INFO: %s", message.format(package_name=candidate.name))

Description

Sensitive information leakage through logger messages can compromise data security. This vulnerability arises when sensitive data is inadvertently included in log messages, posing a risk of unauthorized disclosure.

Remediations

  • Do not include sensitive data in logger messages. This can lead to unintentional exposure of private information.

    logger.info(f"User is: '{user.email}'") # unsafe

  • Do use non-sensitive, unique identifiers to log user information. This approach maintains privacy and security.

    logger.info(f"User is: '{user.uuid}'")

References

  • OWASP Logging Cheat Sheet

Usage of weak hashing library (MDx) medium

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_hash_md5  CWE: CWE 328  Fingerprint: 6c3bc980cde523dddae407d687be131c_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/passlib/handlers/cisco.py:214

214 digest = md5(secret).digest()

Description

Using a weak hashing library, such as MD5, increases the risk of data breaches. MD5 itself is vulnerable to collision attacks, where two different inputs can produce the same hash value, compromising data integrity and security.

Remediations

  • Do not use MD5 for hashing. This algorithm is considered weak and vulnerable to attacks.

    hashlib.md5('password').digest() # unsafe

  • Do opt for stronger hashing algorithms like SHA-256 to enhance security.

    hashlib.sha256('password').digest()

Usage of weak hashing library (MDx) medium

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_hash_md5  CWE: CWE 328  Fingerprint: e54b2e43b8ca0f7bf41f0b401c84e226_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/passlib/handlers/digests.py:126

126 return hashlib.md5(data).hexdigest()

Description

Using a weak hashing library, such as MD5, increases the risk of data breaches. MD5 itself is vulnerable to collision attacks, where two different inputs can produce the same hash value, compromising data integrity and security.

Remediations

  • Do not use MD5 for hashing. This algorithm is considered weak and vulnerable to attacks.

    hashlib.md5('password').digest() # unsafe

  • Do opt for stronger hashing algorithms like SHA-256 to enhance security.

    hashlib.sha256('password').digest()

Usage of weak hashing library (MDx) medium

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_hash_md5  CWE: CWE 328  Fingerprint: 9b9fedc549b311781159ac59d670c1eb_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/passlib/handlers/django.py:162

162 return str_to_uascii(md5(self.salt.encode("ascii") + secret).hexdigest())

Description

Using a weak hashing library, such as MD5, increases the risk of data breaches. MD5 itself is vulnerable to collision attacks, where two different inputs can produce the same hash value, compromising data integrity and security.

Remediations

  • Do not use MD5 for hashing. This algorithm is considered weak and vulnerable to attacks.

    hashlib.md5('password').digest() # unsafe

  • Do opt for stronger hashing algorithms like SHA-256 to enhance security.

    hashlib.sha256('password').digest()

Usage of weak hashing library (SHA-1) medium

Rule ID: python_lang_weak_hash_sha1  CWE: CWE 328  Fingerprint: 70bfd7b38f5029ae46de59f141371e80_0

Filename: .venv/Lib/site-packages/cryptography/x509/extensions.py:72

72 return hashlib.sha1(data).digest()

Description

Using a weak hashing library like SHA-1 increases the risk of data breaches. SHA-1 in particular is vulnerable to collision attacks, where two different inputs can produce the same hash value, compromising data integrity and security.

Remediations

  • Do not use SHA-1 for hashing. It is no longer considered secure due to its vulnerability to collision attacks.

    hashlib.sha1('password').digest() # unsafe

  • Do opt for stronger hashing algorithms such as SHA-256 to enhance security.

    hashlib.sha256('password').digest()

Usage of weak hashing library (SHA-1) medium

Remediations

  • Do not use SHA-1 for hashing. It is no longer considered secure due to its vulnerability to collision attacks.

    hashlib.sha1('password').digest() # unsafe

  • Do opt for stronger hashing algorithms such as SHA-256 to enhance security.

    hashlib.sha256('password').digest()
